channel.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
channel.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 Cable News Network LP, LLLP.

image.title: CNN.com - Top Stories
image.description: CNN.com delivers up-to-the-minute news and information on the latest top stories, weather, entertainment, politics and more.

item.title: Real Madrid top football rich list
item.description: Real Madrid and Atletico Madrid will go head-to-head later this month to decide which football club is the finest in Europe but, when it comes to the bottom line, there is only one winner.

item.title: Football failing in racism strategy
item.description: "You can be as racist as you want, as long as you keep your mouth shut," says John Barnes.

item.title: Serena forced to withdraw in Madrid
item.description: Serena Williams was forced to pull out of the Madrid Open with a thigh injury ahead of her quarter final tie with Petra Kvitova Friday.

item.title: Kaymer holds lead at Sawgrass
item.description: Martin Kaymer built upon his record equaling opening round of 63 at Sawgrass Friday to head the Players Championship at the halfway stage.

item.title: The world's most traveled horse
item.description: The air miles don't accrue, there's no free holiday to aspire to at the end of it, and the flights are seemingly never ending.

item.title: What Beats by Apple would mean
item.description: It's an odd pairing, really, the gadget-obsessed tech giant from Silicon Valley teaming up with hip-hop super producer Dr. Dre and music mogul Jimmy Iovine.

item.title: U.S. needs to help return girls
item.description: Three weeks ago, 276 girls awoke to a nightmare.

item.title: Hillary Clinton's Boko Haram problem
item.description: Newt Gingrich says Clinton's leadership as secretary of state regarding the Nigerian terrorist group Boko Haram is open to question.

item.title: It's time to televise executions
item.description: 'Humane' executions only put distance between the criminal and the people, trial expert says.

item.title: S. Sudan rivals sign cease-fire after months of mass killings
item.description: South Sudan's President has reached a cease-fire deal with a rebel leader following five months of violence in the world's youngest nation.

item.title: Hot air balloon catches fire; 3 missing
item.description: A hot air balloon burst into flames and crashed in Virginia on Friday night, prompting a search for the wreckage and the three people believed to be on board.

item.title: ANC wins South African elections
item.description: The African National Congress has won South Africa's general election, holding onto power despite scandals, economic woes and corruption allegations that some felt might weaken its grip.

item.title: S. Korean ferry toll rises to 275
item.description: The death toll from the South Korean ferry capsizing has gone up to 275, with dozens more still missing, the nation's officials said Saturday.

item.title: Putin in Crimea for Victory Day
item.description: Violent clashes break out in Ukraine's flashpoint city of Mariupol where CNN's Nick Paton Walsh says there are reports of an ongoing battle for a police station.

item.title: Battle for police station
item.description: Nick Paton Walsh reports on deadly clashes between pro-Russian militants and government forces in Mariupol, Ukraine.

item.title: Russian military pride on display
item.description: CNN's Matthew Chance reports on the military show of force in Russia on Victory Day as tensions with Ukraine continue.

item.title: AQ-linked militants killed in Yemen
item.description: Eleven "al Qaeda terrorists" were killed by Yemeni security forces Friday, two Yemeni Defense Ministry officials told CNN.

item.title: Ukraine crisis gives Eurovision edge
item.description: Why Europe's annual singalong has an extra political edge.

item.title: Fatal quake hits Pakistan
item.description: At least two people were killed and more than 40 others were injured in a series of relatively minor earthquakes in southern Pakistan early Friday, the country's state-run news agency reported.

item.title: Raids target Venezuela protesters
item.description: The Venezuelan government detained 243 protesters in a swift, predawn operation targeting four campsites set up at public squares around Caracas, the capital.

item.title: Demonstrators face crackdown
item.description: CNN's Rafael Romo reports on the swift operation cracking down on demonstrators in Venezuela by the government.

item.title: Singer Chris Brown jailed
item.description: Singer Chris Brown on Friday admitted to violating his probation and was ordered by a judge to serve one year in jail.

item.title: Mother shot in CAR violence
item.description: Moments after breastfeeding her baby, Didiatou Hassam was shot in the head.

item.title: Race rant CEO offers explanation
item.description: In a yet another audio recording, Los Angeles Clippers owner Donald Sterling purportedly explains why he infamously told a woman not to bring black people to his games: He was jealous that she was with black men.

item.title: Crack epidemic haunts Brazil
item.description: Addicts smoke in open air crack dens on streets that soon will be full of World Cup fans.

item.title: Pistorius defense disputes evidence
item.description: One of the most respected ballistics experts in South Africa disputed key elements of the prosecution case against Oscar Pistorius Friday, saying that the girlfriend he killed last year did not appear to have been in a defensive position when he shot her.

item.title: Drones are N. Korean, South says
item.description: Call them drones; call them toy airplanes with digital cameras shoved into their entrails.

item.title: Berlusconi starts community service
item.description: Former Italian Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi began a year of community service for his conviction on tax fraud charges on Friday when he showed up at a senior center near his hometown, Milan.

item.title: Cargo door alert on Singapore A380
item.description: A Singapore Airlines flight to Hong Kong had to turn back in mid-flight Friday after the pilots received an alert about a problem with a cargo door on the plane, the company said.

item.title: Rooney's widow contests will
item.description: Mickey Rooney's widow has filed a challenge against the validity of the will the legendary actor signed just weeks before his death at 93, her lawyer said.

item.title: Amnesty: Nigeria 'warned of raid'
item.description: Amnesty International accuses Nigerian military commanders of knowing Boko Haram was heading to a school at least four hours before abductions; Nigeria denies the claim.

item.title: Minister: Nigeria isn't on trial
item.description: Isha Sesay talks to Nigeria's Minister of Information about the reported slow government response to the kidnapping.

item.title: Escaped girls describe trauma
item.description: Pledges of help are doing little to comfort the parents of nearly 300 Nigerian girls kidnapped by Boko Haram.

item.title: What you need to know
item.description: It's been more than three weeks since militants from the dreaded Boko Haram terrorist group dragged 276 girls out of their beds at a boarding school in northern Nigeria, and still no one knows where the girls are. International assistance has begun to flow into Nigeria, whose president has vowed to end the terror threat plaguing his country.

item.title: Girls likely taken across border
item.description: Nigeria's president vows that audacious kidnapping will be Boko Haram's undoing, but admits that girls have likely been scattered and moved out of the country.

item.title: Rare fish washes ashore
item.description: A rare sturgeon washed ashore in Lyme, Connecticut. WTNH's Tina Detelj reports.

item.title: Knox: I can prove my innocence
item.description: CNN's Chris Cuomo sat down for an exclusive interview with Amanda Knox.

item.title: Adams: I reject allegations
item.description: Christiane Amanpour speaks to Sinn Fein Pres. Gerry Adams who insists he had no connection with Jean McConville's death.

item.title: Pistorius: Murder or mistake?
item.description: As the Paralympian takes the stand in the Reeva Steenkamp murder trial, CNN's Richard Greene looks back at the key points made by the prosecution.

item.title: Neymar on Santos transfer
item.description: Amanda Davies talks with Brazilian superstar Neymar about his transfer from Barcelona to Santos and World Cup protests.

item.title: Voices from Ukraine
item.description: As militant forces take over government buildings in eastern Ukraine, Pro-Russian and Pro-Ukrainian protesters are on conflicting sides.

item.title: Ukraine and Russia face off at Eurovision
item.description: Eurovision expert William Lee Adams explains how political tensions between the two countries could spill into the contest.

item.title: Escaped girls describe kidnapping
item.description: Pledges of help are doing little to comfort the parents of nearly 300 Nigerian girls kidnapped by Boko Haram.

item.title: Does papyrus say Jesus had a wife?
item.description: A newly-discovered relic suggests that Jesus had a wife. Fordham University Professor Michael Peppard weighs in.

item.title: Pro-Russian militants plan to defy Putin
item.description: Despite Putin's wishes, pro-Russian militants say they'll continue with their referendum vote. Nick Paton Walsh reports.

item.title: Escaped girls describe kidnapping
item.description: Pledges of help are doing little to comfort the parents of nearly 300 Nigerian girls kidnapped by Boko Haram.

item.title: A look at the rare megamouth shark
item.description: A museum in Japan is putting a rare megamouth shark on display.

item.title: Sole survivor of massacre speaks
item.description: Ikenna Nzeribe was shot in the face during a Boko Haram attack on his church.

item.title: Father: Nothing has been done
item.description: The heartbroken father of two girls kidnapped by Boko Haram talks to CNN's Isha Sesay.

item.title: Q&A: Abducted girl crisis
item.description: It's been more than three weeks since militants from the dreaded Boko Haram terrorist group dragged 276 girls out of their beds at a boarding school in northern Nigeria, and still no one knows where the girls are. International assistance has begun to flow into Nigeria, whose president has vowed to end the terror threat plaguing his country.

item.title: Get education out of cross hairs
item.description: The kidnapping of girls isn't new -- just the outrage over it. Will the world act?

item.title: Nnaji on abductions
item.description: CNN's Max Foster talks to the "Julia Roberts of Nigeria," about the government's response to the kidnapped schoolgirls.

item.title: Ukraine crisis gives Eurovision an edge
item.description: Why Europe's annual singalong has an extra political edge.

item.title: China, Vietnam, Philippines collide
item.description: Border disputes across the South China Sea stir tensions.

item.title: The most popular baby names are ...
item.description: Michael and Jacob, your reign has ended.

item.title: Hunting down 'fiery serpent' disease
item.description: The larvae grow inside you, then burst out of your leg. But Guinea worm is being beaten.

item.title: China, Vietnam, Philippines collide
item.description: Border disputes across the South China Sea stir tensions.

item.title: The most popular baby names are ...
item.description: Michael and Jacob, your reign has ended.

item.title: Meet China's military monkey recruits
item.description: The People's Liberation Army Air Force has a new secret weapon.

item.title: Would you pay to launch this airline?
item.description: You've finished your business in London and want to head directly home to New York.

item.title: Thanks for being my 'other mom'
item.description: CNN celebrates women who have loved and nurtured children who were not biologically their own.

item.title: New life engineered with artificial DNA
item.description: Scientists have shown it is possible to alter DNA's alphabet and still have a living organism that passes on the genetic information.

item.title: Want to change Africa? Let's do it!
item.description: As Tanzania's "broker of ideas," social activist Rakesh Rajani has dedicated his life to helping people in East Africa reach their potential. He says the secret to prosperity is to make citizens part of the solution and work from the ground up.

item.title: Football's Monopoly game -- fair or farce?
item.description: Three small letters striking like a dagger to the heart of football's richest football clubs.

item.title: How our universe grew up
item.description: Scientists are using computer algorithms to come up with a detailed representation of how our universe evolved.

item.title: Has U.S. learned from 'War on Terror'?
item.description: How can U.S. ensure Nigeria is not left like Iraq and Afghanistan?

item.title: Bring on the dancing horses?
item.description: While most people can appreciate the grace and athleticism of ballet, dressage -- the precision art of horse riding and training -- remains a puzzling spectacle to all but a few.

item.title: Why U.S. suburban dream went global
item.description: Ubiquitous U.S. suburban home spreads around globe.

item.title: Nintendo defends 'anti-gay' game
item.description: CNN talks to the "Miiquality" Campaign's Tye Marini about why he wants same-sex marriage in a virtual reality game.

item.title: Soccer spending: Fair as Monopoly?
item.description: CNN's Alex Thomas explains the UEFA rules on financial fair play and how that impacts club spending.

item.title: Asia's best beer bars: 10 top pours
item.description: The craft beer revolution is dead. Microbrews are no longer a trend.

item.title: Jennifer Lawrence: Why I keep tripping
item.description: Jennifer Lawrence explains why she keeps tripping up at the Oscars.

item.title: 20 most polluted cities in the world
item.description: Air quality in most cities that monitor their pollution levels exceed what the World Health Organization deems as safe.

item.title: 'Two more Chinas' by the year 2050
item.description: Carl Safina says contrary to what the "Growthers" think, it's a finite world, and the way to fight hunger and conflict and stop the extinction of animals is to rein in the world's growing population.

item.title: Check out this rare megamouth shark
item.description: A museum in Japan is putting a rare megamouth shark on display.

item.title: See solar explosion caught on camera
item.description: Meteorologist Chad Myers details what a solar explosion is after NASA released images of one caught on their cameras.

item.title: 6 takeaways from Lewinsky essay
item.description: The intern whose affair nearly brought down Bill Clinton's presidency tells all in Vanity Fair.

item.title: Australia shark cull stirs controversy
item.description: Shark mitigation program sees dozens of large sharks killed -- but are they the right ones?

item.title: Soccer's 10 most valuable teams
item.description: Titles are up for grabs across Europe -- but who's the financial winner?

item.title: Banksy blessing for boys' art find
item.description: A struggling English youth club could have its fortunes turned around, thanks to a rather unusual gift.

item.title: Liberia: Don't believe what Google says
item.description: Unhappy with Liberia's image on the Internet, a photographer decided to present his own view, using GIFs.

item.title: What are the real reasons we yawn?
item.description: A new study suggests that you may not really be yawning because it's contagious, or you're bored or tired.

item.title: It holds how many million songs?
item.description: Forget the cloud, and rework your mental image of those mysterious data centers. Sony has reinvented a tool for storing a mind-numbing amount of data:

item.title: Ukraine tension to hit Eurovision?
item.description: Could political tensions between Ukraine and Russia spill over into the song contest?

item.title: Fillies fly first class for $50,000
item.description: The air miles don't accrue, there's no free holiday to aspire to at the end of it, and the flights are seemingly never ending.

item.title: Get girls' education out of the cross hairs
item.description: The kidnapping of girls during war isn't new, but the outrage is. What is the world willing to do about it?

item.title: Father: Nothing has been done
item.description: The heartbroken father of two girls kidnapped by Boko Haram talks to CNN's Isha Sesay.

item.title: Q&A: Abducted girl crisis
item.description: It's been more than three weeks since militants from the dreaded Boko Haram terrorist group dragged 276 girls out of their beds at a boarding school in northern Nigeria, and still no one knows where the girls are. International assistance has begun to flow into Nigeria, whose president has vowed to end the terror threat plaguing his country.

item.title: Man played dead to survive massacre
item.description: Ikenna Nzeribe was the sole survivor after assassins from Boko Haram stormed his Nigerian church in 2012, just 60 miles from where the jihadists last month abducted more than 200 girls.

item.title: Nnaji on abductions
item.description: CNN's Max Foster talks to the "Julia Roberts of Nigeria," about the government's response to the kidnapped schoolgirls.

item.title: The world's most polluted city is...
item.description: Air quality in most cities that monitor their pollution levels exceed what the World Health Organization deems to be safe. Here are the world's 20 dirtiest cities.

item.title: Climate change is here, action needed now: White House report
item.description: Climate change is here and will only worsen. Get used to more flooding, wildfires and drought, depending on where you live. Cities and states across America already are spending lots of money to respond.

item.title: Drone, jetliner in near miss in Florida
item.description: A drone nearly collided with a commercial airliner, says U.S. aviation official.

item.title: Nnaji: Won't stop until girls are back
item.description: Nigerian superstar Genevieve Nnaji speaks out for the kidnapped girls, saying the country is united against "this inhumane act."

item.title: Hunting down 'fiery serpent' disease
item.description: The larvae grow inside you, then burst out of your leg. But Guinea worm is being beaten.

item.title: Nigeria
item.description: U.S. military officials arrive in Nigeria to help in the search for hundreds of girls kidnapped by Islamist militants three weeks ago.

item.title: Military monkeys
item.description: The People's Liberation Army Air Force has a new secret weapon.

item.title: 'Serpent' disease
item.description: Guinea worm disease once infected millions -- now it's almost eradicated. But can we catch the final cases?

item.title: Glamorous Orient Express
item.description: In 1883, what was to become the iconic Orient Express train pulled out of Paris' Gare de l'Est on its maiden voyage to Istanbul, or Constantinople as it was known at the time.

item.title: Andy Warhol's lost art
item.description: The soup can looks familiar in an unfamiliar way, but the name at the bottom of the image is unmistakable: Andy Warhol.

item.title: Mastery of Easter eggs
item.description: French fashion designers don't hold a monopoly on haute.

item.title: From humble GIF to high art
item.description: When you think of GIFs, those never-ending sequences of looping motion, you're more likely to associate them with lightly humorous viral content than a respectable art form.

item.title: The world's top furniture fair
item.description: This year around 300,000 visitors are expected to attend the Milan's Salone del Mobile, the world's largest and most important furniture fair.

item.title: Rise of the mega-museums
item.description: From the British Museum to the Louvre, the world's leading museums house treasured artifacts and storied works of art. They may protect centuries of culture, but they don't want to be perceived as dusty relics themselves.

item.title: How to buy a great watch
item.description: In recent days the good and the great of the watch and jewelry industry have descended on Basel, Switzerland for Baselworld 2014the biggest and most ballyhooed event on the industry calendar. Running until April 3, the fair is expected to attract more than 150,000 visitors, who will ogle at the latest gadgets and admire glittering new designs.

item.title: Enter into Congo's cult of elegance
item.description: Known as "Sapeurs," these dapper dressers are part of a Congolese subculture devoted to the cult of style.

item.title: A one of a kind friendship
item.description: A two-legged chihuahua and a fluffy chicken have become best friends.

item.title: I was an accomplice to my brother's suicide
item.description: "Funny, happy people do not kill themselves. It doesn't make sense."

item.title: Learning to talk with autism
item.description: Bobby Smith's mother, like all parents, looked forward to the day when her baby could use words to tell her what was wrong. What hurts? Why are you sad?

item.title: Why superheroes are good for kids
item.description: Two of my eldest son's first words were "Dada" and "Batman." (Or "Batmah," at least.)

item.title: Vintage photos: World's Fair
item.description: While digging through a box that belonged to his father, Robert Ondrovic uncovered a collection of vintage photos that brought him back to the 1964 World's Fair.

item.title: $1,000 tip for dog's surgery
item.description: Good people, not to mention good tippers, do exist. Christina Summitt knows that for sure now after what happened Saturday night.

item.title: Extreme surf photography
item.description: Kenji Croman has broken bones, dislocated his shoulder and elbow, endured concussions and nearly drowned several times.

item.title: China's secret weapon
item.description: The Chinese air force have a new secret weapon: monkeys.

item.title: South China Sea tensions rise
item.description: Tensions escalated in the South China Sea region this week after China, Vietnam and the Philippines were involved in a series of potentially explosive confrontations over disputed territory.

item.title: HK's biggest ever corruption trial
item.description: Two billionaire brothers who control Asia's biggest property development company have gone on trial in Hong Kong's biggest ever corruption case.

item.title: Journalist arrested over secrets
item.description: Prominent Chinese journalist and press freedom advocate Gao Yu has been detained for allegedly leaking state secrets, China's state-run news agency Xinhua reported Thursday.

item.title: Tiananmen at 25: Five activists held
item.description: Five people have been detained in Beijing after they attended a low-key event marking the 25th anniversary of the Tiananmen Square crackdown.

item.title: China's mental health care crisis
item.description: Wu Yuanhong, a man suffering from schizophrenia in China's southeastern Jiangxi Province, was forced by his mother to live in a small metal cage for 11 years after he beat a young boy to death.

item.title: SARS lessons for MERS prevention
item.description: Hong Kong generally gets a bad rap when it comes to infectious diseases.

item.title: China protects against poaching
item.description: Curbing China's appetite for wild game is just the beginning of the war against illegal poaching, say conservationists.
